content.text: Once upon a time, in a small village nestled between rolling green hills and a whispering bamboo forest, there lived an old man and his wife.
The old man was kind and gentle, with a heart as warm as the morning sun.
His wife, however, was quite the opposite—she was cross and grumpy, always scolding and never satisfied.
One day, while the old man was sweeping the garden, he found a tiny sparrow with a broken wing.
Its feathers were ruffled, and it chirped pitifully, unable to fly. The old man’s heart melted.
"Oh, poor little thing," he said, carefully picking it up.
He took it inside, made a cozy nest for it in a small basket, and fed it grains and water.
Day after day, he nursed the sparrow back to health, singing to it and whispering kind words.
The sparrow grew stronger, and soon its wing healed.
It hopped about the house, chirping happily, and the old man grew very fond of it.
But the old woman did not share his kindness. "Shoo, shoo!" she would snap whenever the sparrow came near.
"Useless little bird, always making a mess!" She grumbled about the seeds it scattered and the chirping that disturbed her naps.
One morning, the old woman was preparing rice paste to starch her husband’s clothes.
The sparrow, curious as birds often are, fluttered down and pecked at the paste.
The old woman shrieked in anger. "You greedy little thing!" she cried, grabbing a pair of scissors.
Before the old man could stop her, she snipped off the sparrow’s tongue.
"Now you’ll never steal again!" she hissed.
The sparrow let out a pained chirp and fluttered away, disappearing into the bamboo forest.
The old man was heartbroken. "How could you be so cruel?" he scolded his wife.
But she only huffed and turned away. Days passed, and the old man missed his little friend terribly.
One evening, as the sun dipped below the hills, he decided to search for the sparrow.
He walked deep into the bamboo forest, calling out, "Little sparrow, where are you?
I’m so sorry for what happened. Please come back!"  After wandering for some time, he heard a faint chirp.
Following the sound, he came upon a grand bamboo grove where a beautiful sparrow sat perched on a branch.
"Oh, kind old man," the sparrow said in a soft voice, "I am the one you nursed back to health.
Though my tongue was cut, I have found a new home here with my sparrow friends."  The old man’s eyes filled with tears.
"I’m so sorry for what my wife did.
I never meant for you to be hurt."  The sparrow fluttered down and landed on his shoulder.
"Do not be sad," it said. "I have forgiven her, for I know she did not understand kindness.
But because you were so good to me, I wish to repay your kindness." The sparrow led him to a small bamboo hut where two chests sat side by side—one large and ornate, the other small and plain.
"Choose one," the sparrow said.
"But remember, what you take will reflect the goodness in your heart."  The old man thought carefully.
He did not need riches or fine things; he only wanted what was simple and true.
"I will take the small chest," he said. The sparrow nodded approvingly.
"A wise choice." It opened the small chest, and inside were gold coins, jewels, and treasures beyond imagining.
The old man gasped in amazement. "This is too much! I cannot take all this!"  But the sparrow insisted.
"It is yours, for your kindness has earned it." The old man thanked the sparrow again and again before hurrying home, his heart light with joy.
When he returned, he showed his wife the treasure. Her eyes gleamed with greed.
"Where did you get this?" she demanded.
The old man told her the whole story—the sparrow’s kindness, the two chests, and his choice.
The old woman’s mind raced with greed.
"If the small chest held such riches, imagine what the large one must contain!" she cried.
Without a moment’s hesitation, she rushed into the bamboo forest, calling out, "Sparrow! Sparrow!
I am here to claim my reward!"  The sparrow appeared, just as it had for the old man.
"Ah, old woman," it said, "I see you have come for a gift.
Very well, choose a chest—large or small."  The old woman did not hesitate.
"The large one, of course!" she snapped. The sparrow sighed.
"As you wish." It opened the large chest, and out poured snakes, toads, and all manner of creepy-crawly things.
The old woman shrieked and ran away as fast as her legs could carry her, the creatures hissing and slithering after her.
From that day on, the old woman learned her lesson.
She stopped being so cross and grumpy, and she even began to help her husband care for the other animals in the village.
As for the old man, he lived happily, sharing his good fortune with those in need.
And sometimes, if you walk through the bamboo forest at dusk, you might just hear the soft chirping of a sparrow—singing a song of kindness and second chances.
